title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [11 november 1868]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [11 November 1868]
text: 11 Nov. 1868My dear Walteri got both of your letters one the last of last week and the other on mondayMonday i got one from Heyde yesterday tuesdayTuesday) saying hannaHannahh was improving but had a bad thumb but no fever i think itsit's pretty hard to tell how she is by his letters but i think she must be quite smart he said she had the girl that they had when i was there she was very good and thought very much of han and will doodo very well for her i make no doubt)well walterWalter dear we are getting along quite smart mattyMatty is improving but far from well the doctor is doctoring her throat with great sucsesssuccess i think he has performed two moderate opperationsoperations on her throat) but O dear if you could hear her talk it would make me hoarse to talk a steady stream as she does when any one comes in to see her i dread to see any one come in i talk and talk to her but it does no manner of good she gets almost offended at me Perbasco was here the other evening and staidstayed quite late and the way matsMatt's toungtongue went it certainly would have made me have had the headachheadache to have talked such a length of time steady but so it is she went out the other day i said dontdon't go to any place but i knew in reason she would so she went to saywards and stayed till dark it was real chilly when she comcome i said marthaMartha if ever any one tryedtried to not get well i think you doodo so that night she raised some blood not much but it frightened her staidstayed and talked till it got so late and then walked fast home that was the cause of it when we doodo every thing to have her comfortable it makes me real out of patience) Edd has been quite sick with billiousbilious attack but is so he does a little now but looks very bad) off georgeGeorge has got a draw of the two houses they talk of building he got the furniture insured to day for 400 dollarsgood bie walterWalteri am pretty smart at present i try to get along as easy as i can mattyMatty is very weak she cantcan't do much nevenever mind Walter it will be spring after a while Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [11 November 1868]
